article_text: Roth MKM raised the firm’s   on Walmart ( ) to $108 from $97 and keeps a Buy rating on the shares after its results and outlook.  Deceleration has spooked some investors, but the company’s FY26 guidance is simply a baseline for any given year, and absent calendar impacts and M&A, constant-currency operating income guidance is slightly ahead of initial guides for FY25, the analyst tells investors in a research note.  Roth adds that it does not believe that Walmart operations have changed in any meaningful way from FY25 results and expects the post earnings weakness to be bought.

article_text:
Chipmaker AMD   is thinking about selling two factories in New Jersey and Texas in a deal that could be worth around $4 billion, according to  . Indeed, several Asian companies, including Compal Electronics, Inventec, Pegatron, and Wistron, are interested in buying the factories. This potential sale is a significant development for AMD, which has been working to expand its presence in the technology industry. In fact, AMD bought a company called ZT Systems in 2024 for $4.9 billion. This purchase helped AMD improve its   technology and data center capabilities thanks to its expertise in designing cloud computing solutions, which has helped AMD’s cloud and enterprise customers deploy   infrastructure more efficiently. Now, AMD might sell the factories it got from ZT Systems, which could suggest that there is a shift in the company’s strategy. If the sale happens, it could be announced by the summer, specifically in the second quarter. The company will likely continue to focus on developing its technology and expanding its customer base, but the sale of these factories could have significant implications for AMD’s future growth and direction. Interestingly, AMD’s stock price is down over 2% at the time of writing.
		 Turning to Wall Street, analysts have a Moderate Buy consensus rating on AMD stock based on 25 Buys, 11 Holds, and one Sell assigned in the past three months, as indicated by the graphic below. After   over the past year, the   of $147.88 per share implies 33.6% upside potential.

article_text: UBS downgraded TFI International ( ) to Neutral from Buy with a   of $107, down from $163. The firm says its core thesis of less-than-truckload margin expansion is no longer intact. UBS no longer has visibility to a path of significant margin improvement in their TFI’s LTL business following the Q4 report. The analyst views share loss a growing concern considering the “much worse than expected” Q4 performance and TFI’s commentary of continuing challenges in the first half of 2025.

article_text: Citi says cruise operators Carnival ( ), Royal Caribbean ( ), Norwegian Cruise Line ( ), and Viking Holdings ( ) traded down yesterday after Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick specifically referenced cruise lines when speaking of foreign entities bypassing taxes by operating under non-U.S. flags. The firm believes the likelihood of the cruise operators becoming full taxpayers “remains exceedingly low.” However, this is the wrong kind of attention for the companies and would put a “meaningful dent” in earnings and cash flow were this to come to fruition, the analyst tells investors in a research note. Citi believes a more plausible scenario would be for the cruise industry to pay some taxes as a way to “assuage the issue and perhaps reach a resolution. However, this is a situation that cruise operators have long fought to avoid, adds the firm.
title: Citi sees ‘exceedingly low’ chance of cruises paying full U.S. taxes
summary: Cruise operators Carnival, Royal Caribbean, Norwegian Cruise Line and Viking Holdings traded down yesterday. Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick specifically referenced cruise lines when speaking of foreign entities bypassing taxes by operating under non-U.S. flags.
